Pros:
unlimited PTO
Great products
Stability
Cons: Average pay compared to competitors

Pros:
1.  If you love tech, this is a great place.  No doubt you'll talk tech (mostly the MSFT stack) from enterprise to consumer - from PCs to phones to Xboxes - from datacenter to desktop.

2.  What were GREAT benefits are now VERY GOOD (took a small step down) but still probably better than you'll find at 99% of large corporations.  If you've got family - the value of the benefits is even higher.  401k match is nice.

3.  Even with it's struggles MSFT is still a cash printing machine.  This means if you can keep your nose clean and do reasonable work, you can have a stable job, pay your bills, feed your family, and not worry (too much) about layoffs.  The stock you own likely won't tank, but probably won't go up much either.  You'll get a bonus each year and some stock.  It's a decent life if you aren't looking to light the world on fire.
Cons:
Brand on Your Resume:  After many years of losing market share and struggling to be at the front end of innovation and the fact that there's 90,000 employees, don't think MSFT is necessarily going to be attractive on your resume to more agile and smaller companies.

Managing Your Career:  Make you say this out loud so it registers - 90,000 employees work there.  Double that for vendors.  It is VERY hard to "stand out" and move up in the company.  Don't expect your manager to be much of an advocate or enabler to help you meet your career goals - they are basically trying to survive the stack rank every year too.  Not familiar with the stack rank?  Check out the 2012 Vanity Fair article called "Microsoft's Lost Decade".

Pros: A decent salary and benefits, all things considered
Cons: The expectation to grow products exponentially, but bureaucracy and lack of autonomy hamper your ability to actually execute on any sort of ambitious vision.

Pros:
* I constantly felt like there was a steady flow of very talented people, Not only are people brilliant but also open to mutual growth and learning.
* Exceptional cultural patience, especially within the New England management team, where time and space were generously given for individuals to grow and integrate.
* The company’s scale and appetite for calculated risk created abundant opportunities, which I was empowered to pursue and make the most of really making for an awesome career.
* Microsoft has a remarkable ability to hire genuinely kind and caring individuals. I deeply valued and admired the ICs I worked alongside.
Cons:
* Senior leadership(CVP level) often impedes progress with decisions that feel disconnected from the realities of product development and customer needs. CVPs and above are disjoint from building and customer feedback process and are difficult and even resistant to involve or inform. This can lead to erratic decision-making canceling projects then months later restarting them as competitors did it, people working on the same thing but in nuanced different ways.
* CVPs really are neglecting areas where the Microsoft brand is strong, in favor of "red ocean" areas where Microsoft could succeed but would face tremendous friction.
* Microsoft is moving to a culture of layoffs where they are not based on performance or any meaningful metric often eliminating people who are incredibly talented devoted and loyal over people who really are stagnant.
* PM leadership continuously fails to define a strategy in any meaningful way to help organize IC teams.

Pros: Good pay, leaves a bit to be desired when compared to other big tech, but in general quite solid. Culture is generally great, benefits are fantastic. Lots of opportunities for growth. Having Microsoft on your resume is obviously a huge plus. Tons of opportunity to work with some incredibly smart, talented people. Management will fight for you on your behalf if you have the right skills and mindset.
Cons: Big shift lately towards an Amazon-like performance culture and less trust placed in employees. Lots of bureaucracy that makes it difficult to truly innovate. Pay is not good enough IMO for the second largest company in the world (market cap). Lots of values that are thrown out and sound really good, but in practice -- especially as you move up -- are essentially thrown out the window. Feels like MSFT bought too many GPUs without figuring out how to make it actually profitable, and the employees are paying the price.

Pros: Great benefits.  People take great pride in the work they do.  Microsoft is always at the forefront of technology and innovation.
Cons: The role is seen as at the bottom.  Other roles are promoted more frequently and if you haven’t forged good relationships with those you work with, you’ll find their feedback can severely tarnish your year end review.  You can really learn a lot in this role but it can be difficult to have a career doing this. While there are some that have done so, it’s advisable to leverage the learning opportunities to move into other roles as quickly as you can.  This is also one of the only roles that have you on call 24/7.  They’ll tell you that you don’t have to answer the phone at 1am but if something goes awry and you don’t answer, you own the accountability.

Pros: Great benefits, great people, great place to learn
Cons: They will lay you off in a heartbeat if it makes any level of sense to them. There is no loyalty to employees. I have seen 20+ layoffs with the company in 23 years. I have been laid off twice by them. Be grateful for every day and always keep your resume current and have another plan.

Pros: Great benefits, amazing people and the chance to work on some of the best products in the industry.
Cons: After having my most successful year at Microsoft (Excellent Connect Review, Bonuses and Raises) I was laid off after 15 years with the company. Why? Age (I am over 55), Years in role, (I was having huge impact but, I had not changed roles in over 5 years because I loved what I did and was having impact doing it) and Salary (I was at the top end of the salary). I am glad I left now that meeting 100% of your Connect objectives is now seen as only reaching 80% of them, This means MSFT can hire two people with minimal experience and have them work 60-70 hrs a week for the same cost as me that will be happy to change roles every three years. In short, they drew a line, if you were over the line with age, salary, or years in role, you were gone.

Pros:
You might work for one of the most powerful tech companies on Earth, but your clients just want to know:
“How do I reset my Outlook password without calling Steve in IT?”

You're overqualified, underutilized, diplomatically smiling through every meeting, and wielding more buzzwords than actual influence. But hey, at least you’ve got swag, stock options, and an endless supply of acronyms
Cons:
Innovation, Meet Regulation
Trying to introduce Power Platform to a local government agency is like trying to install solar panels on a sinking rowboat. Your big goals? Enable collaboration, improve workflows, modernize services.
Reality? Convince the IT director’s cousin not to unplug the on-prem mail server again

You're supposed to “drive adoption” of Microsoft tools... with clients who still pay invoices via fax. You’re constantly pushing for “modern collaboration,” while begging someone to accept a Teams meeting instead of sending a meeting invite from Lotus Notes

When something actually breaks? You get to say your signature line:
“We’ve engaged engineering and will follow up shortly.”
(Translation: “We emailed someone who’s actively ignoring us.”)

You have no decision-making power. You're like a cloud concierge with a laminated menu no one orders from

Pros: Most folks I met at Microsoft are great people. Because my team is great and my colleagues are dedicated to customer satisfaction, my job is enjoyable. Benefits are great. In the US, we have access to fantastic resources. Well respected company and gives you skills to thrive elsewhere.
Cons: The layoffs have been consistent over the past couple years and it has me in this constant zone of anxiety. I have to keep applying for roles externally just in case and that takes a lot of time. Career growth is very difficult at MS. You have layoffs and many talented people raising their hands for the same role. It’s easy to feel stuck in a job here. It’s all about exposure, your network and the stretch assignments you do outside of your role, to get you known. It can feel exhausting that doing your job isn’t enough. MS doesn’t see the great employees and offer to promote you into a new role, it’s all in your hands. Pay isn’t as good as other tech firms.

Pros:
- Fortunate enough to work with a fantastic, highly knowledgeable team including leadership.
- As part of the few hourly positions at Microsoft, they generally allow many overtime opportunities to help support for CO+I needs to maintain the datacenters up 24/7.
- With a base schedule of 12-hour shifts with 3/4-day work weeks, it provides for great work-life balance.
- The work benefits are pretty amazing compared to many other companies: Being able to maximize your 401(k) with a 50% total limit employer match and available after-tax rollover conversion, $1750 HSA (single) employer contribution, $1500 Perks+, and medical/dental not taken out of your paycheck just to have coverage is phenomenal.
- There are some great opportunities to complete additional professional certifications and gain highly valuable job experience.
- Employee Resource Groups (ERG) are available and provide additional community and support.
- Wonderful career opportunity overall!
Cons:
- Career development with advancement and growth opportunities are available, but they may be limited.
- Pay is "competitive," but it is definitely substantially lower compared to other big tech competitors for similar positions even with the great benefits and stocks.
- Recent layoffs may affect the teammates morale

Pros:
Tech leader with global recognition 
Work with best and brightest - internally and externally
Benefits are still fantastic relative to most places
Cons:
Constant lay-offs and reorgs are indicitive of chaotic leadership - who will apologize and accept responsibility while not actually experiencing any consequences, which comes off as extremely disingenious. Morale in MCAPS is extremely low across the board as people you've worked with for years vanish overnight. Meanwhile, you will have also feel as if you have no job security - even if you are performing well with glowing reviews from your manager - and will constantly wonder when the ball will drop on you or your team. Your friends and co-workers will vanish out of nowhere, and you'll have a constant, nagging feeling of "am I next?" 

Even if you go above and beyond, and do everything that is asked of you - one day you'll wake up and the answer will be "yes, yes you are."

Pros:
Since this is a rotational program, you can try out different projects, and able to figure out what team is a best fit
The pace is not too fast, good work life balance
Cons:
The social environment is very political. Managers put a lot of focus on "visibility" and "leadership", perhaps more than getting results. 
The projects selected are not very thought through. Some of the teams we get teamed up with are toxic, or just have generally no idea about AI and can be difficult to work with.
Promotion evaluation is also not very transparent.

Pros:
The company once had a strong, inclusive culture where employees felt seen, heard, and valued. However, when layoffs began in 2023, it marked a noticeable shift — the culture changed, and things no longer felt the same.

That said, the company offered exceptional benefits, stock options, and valuable experiences. Although I was impacted by the layoffs, I remain grateful for the opportunity and for the incredible people I had the chance to work with..
Cons:
Significant culture shift following 2023 layoffs; the once inclusive and people-first environment felt diminished
Communication became less transparent as organizational changes continued
Uncertainty around job security affected overall morale and team cohesion
Leadership seemed less engaged with employee feedback during periods of transition
Rapid changes led to increased workloads and fewer growth opportunities in later stages

Pros:
benefits, cafeteria, vacation time, flexible hours, medical leave
HR Is a nightmare, do not EVER bring an issue to them you will be targeted for removal
Cons:
- bad computers and equipment on your first day (seriously used/old/dirty computers) and this is your first introduction in how they "include" you - they do not ask what kind of gear you need, and if you need something nobody will help you get it ordered, and you may get directed to an old office that has become a graveyard of bad old equipment to pick through.
- unfriendly coworkers in many cases
- lack of true collaboration in many cases
- they talk about DEI - lots of seminars, but in practice it is not respected ouside the seminars. They get people to confess to imposter syndrome and act like isn't it great to always go around talking about your weakness and those people are the ones who got fired and layed off the first chance they get. 
- they suck interns in like crazy grind them up, then spit them out quickly and they hire so many just to keep other companies from being able to hire the fresh meat.

Pros:
1.	Flexible Work Options – Microsoft offers hybrid and remote-friendly roles, with many teams supporting asynchronous work to accommodate personal schedules.
	2.	Respect for Personal Time – Most managers respect boundaries around non-working hours, and there’s a strong culture of not expecting after-hours emails or meetings unless it’s critical.
	3.	Generous Time Off – Competitive PTO, sick leave, and mental wellness days ensure that employees can recharge when needed.
Cons:
1.	Workload Depends on Team – While the culture supports balance, some high-visibility or customer-facing teams can experience spikes in workload, especially during global events or product launches.
	2.	Always-On Feeling – In global roles, working across time zones may occasionally require early mornings or late meetings, which can blur work-life boundaries over time.

Pros:
Good pay for my position. 
Autonomy on how my day went. 
Great Team culture. 
The manager was visionary and allowed the team to be also.
Cons:
You have to be able to pivot when the business requires it. 
Layoff is now part of the culture and not just a rhythm of the business. It creates a cloud of anxiety that makes it hard for some to perform. 
A decent amount of accessibility focus and design, but learning and skilling is not geared to help those neurodiverse.

Pros:
Incredible smart and collaborative colleagues — you're surrounded by some of the best engineers in the world.

Great compensation and benefits, including generous parental leave, 401k matching, and wellness perks.

Career mobility is strong — it’s possible to switch teams, orgs, or even disciplines with manager support.

Remote/hybrid flexibility has improved a lot since 2020.

Culture encourages work-life balance more than you'd expect from Big Tech.
Cons:
Like many large companies, there’s a lot of process, and decision-making can be slow.

Performance reviews feel a bit opaque, and there's still a "stack ranking" vibe even if unofficial.

Some teams can be hit-or-miss — experiences vary widely depending on your org and manager.

Innovation sometimes takes a backseat to risk aversion in mature product areas.

Pros: Fair compensation. Good people work at field level.
Cons:
Culture has become cut-throat and Job Stability is a roulette.
The gap between the speech of the leadership and their actions is huge. 
Diversity is a PR Stunt focused on the legal definition on it, not on truly diversity of thoughts, skills, preferences
Company is on the habit of using alternate names to hide reality (Like forced curve to evaluate employees and provide bonus).

Pros:
I was so excited when I accepted my role at Microsoft back in 202.  I really thought that I had reached the pinnacle of my career.  Like everything I had worked for up to that point had culminated in my ability to land a role in one of the bluechip companies in the tech industry.  

Unfortunately the problems started right from the beginning.  I got next to no training on my role plus I had come in at a time when the CSAM role was going through a transition so even when I reached out to the veterans to try and gain some insight into how I could make an impact while servicing my clients needs they often responded with the same confusions and frustrations that I was experiencing.  I obviously cannot go into the details of my particular situation but my experience at Microsoft can best be summed up in "setup to fail."
Cons: Before I joined MS I spoke with a former employee who had told me that my entire experience would hinge on the manager I ended up with and boy was that an understatement.  Unfortunately for me I landed under one of the worst managers I have ever worked under.  The reason I am no longer with the company was entirely due to this person sabotaging my progression at the company.

Smart, mission-driven people. Lots of opportunities to take ownership and drive cross-functional impact. Strong compensation and benefits. Great work-life balance depends on the team but is generally respected. Internal mobility is possible with the right network and initiative.
Cons: Bureaucracy can slow down decision-making. Some orgs are siloed. Internal documentation and onboarding processes can be overwhelming, especially in complex technical teams. Career advancement depends heavily on visibility and networking.

Pros: Majority people are kind and genuinely helpful, you get excellent perks, lots of flexibility in scheduling, supportive management to pursue passion projects, myriad of resources to learn and grow, and overall great work life balance with fair pay!
Cons:
Moving internally to different roles requires extensive networking( and some politics). They are considered lateral moves so there are no level changes or pay increases, unless you are moving from individual contributor to management. Also why promotions can be slow moving unless you take the lead on it.  
You are also in a constant state of "building the plane as you fly" and catching up. So lack of clear vision and structure does affects productivity.
More people than work, which explains the layoffs to be honest and a significant culture shift from leadership since 2023.

Pros: Many have left, but there are still some dynamic, deep-diving, technical people working here as devs and managers.
Cons:
Funding is being slashed to feed investments in AI and make stock prices go up. Windows engineering systems infrastructure seems to be on life support, but this is not acknowledged by leadership.

Also, there is no real oversight of managers' performance reviews (internally called Connects). Even if you have hard evidence (emails, history in Azure DevOps tasks/deliverables/scenarios), a bad manager can mark you as Lower Impact Than Expected (LITE) and basically flag you for termination at their personal whim.

Pros: Great benefits, good starting salary, opportunities abound
Cons: Salary does not keep up w/ inflation.  Workload and expectations FAR outpace compensation.  What was once an environment of collaboration and teamwork has returned to a cut throat workforce where your contributions must be greater than your colleagues

Pros: Great pay, decent benefits and you get to work with some great people
Cons: With brutal layoffs, Microsoft has repeatedly demonstrated that they have NO regard for the human beings who work for them. They only care about money. To reduce costs, even though stock is at an all-time high and the company is worth over three TRILLION dollars, this year they laid off or fired thousands of loyal employees with an incredible cumulative amount of brain-power that they have spent decades recruiting, hiring and growing with no notice whatsoever. Looking for a career? Look for a company who wants to give you one instead of this one that just wants to bleed you dry and then throw you away.

Pros:
None compared to other top tech companies

depending on team, impact compared to smaller tech companies
Cons:
- Pay is worse than other top companies
- Work life balance is probably worse than before (but probably still better than Amazon?) 
- AI has fully become the top priority of the company, if you don’t make an impact on this single metric, expect to get laid off
- Higher up management are also bound to the whims of the C-Suite executives and have no idea how to maintain success beyond laying people off and overworking very capable employees

Pros: Decent work-life balance overall, though things can get busy depending on the team and product cycle. You get to work with incredibly smart, driven colleagues and contribute to cutting-edge technology that impacts millions.
Cons: Internal processes and layers of approval can slow down feature development. It sometimes feels like innovation takes a back seat to alignment and planning.

Pros: Working with smart people. Comp package is nice.
Cons: Views employees as cattle. Too much red tape. Teams got political after sensing an impending layoff. This resulted in people working 12 hours a day and work over weekends, all to maintain face to avoid layoffs.

Pros:
Good 401k match
Company (somewhat) values work-life balance (under 50 hours a week)
Free healthcare outside deductible
Mostly work from home. (Subject to Change)
Cons:
Company has no clear vision for employees. 
5k+ layoffs every quarter for the past 2 years.
Low pay increases the last 5 years despite record profits

Pros:
- Individual professionals were a blast to work with
- Generally pays well (so long as you don't move to the "wrong" places)
- Good benefits
Cons:
- Leadership makes decisions that are either baffling ignorant or outright malicious (example: investing billions into developing a new campus in India, but also having several waves of layoffs due to insufficient funding)
- HR tends to be intensely passive aggressive when it comes to dealing with issues. They also can be straight up dismissive and uncaring. In my particular case, I had to move to a new state for personal reasons, so I had to notify them when I signed a new lease for my new place so they could notify me of my newly adjusted salary. Instead of the 10 - 15% reduction at worst they promised, they reduced my salary by 18%. Left several HR tickets over the situation and was promptly ignored. Left a bad taste in my mouth.

Pros: I liked the inclusive and supportive environment. There is a lot of synergy within a team where everyone wants everyone else to succeed.
Cons: It's a big organization and not very agile. There is a lot of duplication of effort. There is a lot of "not my job" and  "that's not your job" when it comes to cross team collaboration.

Pros: The actual worker-level people are generally very down to earth and good folk.
Cons: Pathetic executives doing mass layoffs amid record profits destroying morale across the board. Worthless AI hype obsession rather than actually making good products.

Pros: Work life balance, benefits, and decent culture. Opportunities for growth are there if you have the right personality. Always something new to learn.
Cons: Raises/Promotions are hard to come by if you're not visible enough to management. Culture is dependent on which campus you're at. Technically gifted individuals are often overlooked and neglected. Lack of technical roles in the data center. General career paths are management and project management.

Pros: Good benefits and co workers are actually nice
Cons: Poor management they dont really seem to care much unless its really urgent

Pros:
The benefits were incredible. Microsoft covered premiums for medical/dental/vision. They gave thousands in an HSA card. They matched 50% of 401k contributions up to the IRS limits. All told, probably 30k worth of benefits. 
The work was interesting, at least at first. 
Not too much micromanaging.
Excellent severance package.
Cons:
No job stability. Seemingly at random, groups would get laid off. Might be 10 people this week from a neighboring department. Might be 2000 people next week. My group lasted pretty long, all things considered. Doesn't matter how well your team does, how many projects you complete, your team may be laid off with no warning.
I'm marking DEI as 1 star not due to any personal bad experiences, but rather because they laid off the entire DEI team, so I anticipate things getting worse.
More and more of the work is focused on the AI projects, even when the results of those projects are less than impressive.

Pros:
1. Manager at least I meet are very responsible and helpful
2. There are smart, experienced engineer who is still feel passion about tech around
3. A big company where you can work on different tech stacks.
Cons:
1. Like every big company, politics sometimes influence the long term decision. 
2. Although there are smart, passioned engineer who took responsibility, there are also quite a big portion of engineer who simply do not care and do not interested in 
3. Reward system can be designed better to encourage hard-impactful work people

Pros: The organization offers a great deal of autonomy, and you're surrounded by colleagues who are genuinely willing to support you. Additionally, the benefits provided are among the most competitive I’ve seen in any U.S.-based career.
Cons:
Over the past few years, the frequency and handling of organizational changes have raised significant concerns. These changes often appear abrupt and poorly managed, leading to a sense of instability across teams. There is a growing perception that senior leadership may lack a clear understanding of the day-to-day responsibilities of the roles beneath them—or, perhaps more concerning, that this understanding is not prioritized.
This shift has contributed to a culture where employees feel increasingly expendable. What was once a values-driven and people-focused environment now seems to be primarily centered on financial outcomes. Even in times of strong performance, job security feels uncertain, which undermines morale and trust.

Pros: Pay is fine I guess
Cons: Lack of career options, no internal movement options without going through full dehumanizing interview screening again, posts record profit quarter and celebrates by laying off thousands of employees, every mandate and priority only matters if it cuts costs. Gone is any impetus for creating innovative experiences, quality products, and environments that care about people. AI to cut costs and reduce headcounts and eliminate orgs, they don't hire the brightest nor best people, there's no accountability or consequences for LT and execs, they get away with terrible decisions that sink orgs and cost the company billions by scapegoating the teams under them so they get a bigger bonus by closing studios and firing entire teams that only did what those execs directed them to do. They force you to be on-call 24/7 for long periods of time with no support, bridge calls with thousands of random people around the world for hours and hours on end, sleepless nights with your phone ringing off the hook because they're not interested in improving anything, just maintaining status quo and making it cheaper. We stopped fixing anything more than a year ago and just piled on more half-baked "features" that makes the business "happy" while making every user experience worse, buggier, slower, frustrating and aimless.

Need to be sure to stay sharp on latest trends and notice the writing on the wall or changes will come without notice. Being flexible is key.

Pros:
* Flexible working time with fully remote option
* Compensation is so-so, Microsoft actually pays the least of the big tech companies (at least as of 2025), if you can get in at another big tech company rather do that since you'd be dealing with a lot of nonsense in any big tech company for the salary you're being paid, make every dollar count.
* Stock compensation can be good as long as the stock price are going up, but it serves as "golden handcuffs". If the stock price of Microsoft for whatever reason does not do well it is not worth working here.
Cons:
* Mountains of red tape, stale documentation and bureaucracy that makes working here as an engineer dreadful experience. There can be days that you spend most of the day just navigating the bureaucracy that has nothing to do with actual engineering.
* There's this concept of "One Microsoft" that tries to foster cohesion across teams; this is failing miserably as people are being laid off and teams are increasingly facing higher pressure to deliver on commitments leading to unnecessary push back across team boundaries.
* Your direct manager (and skip level manager) is going to make or break you at this company. If your direct manager is not informed on the engineering side of things or cannot give much guidance regarding engineering processes as a senior/principal engineer, you'd have to pick up the slack for them and potentially do their job. Avoid new (less then 5 years at the company) managers, especially managers that do not learn on the engineering side of things. Try to get into a team with a strong engineering manager that knows what's going on, this will set you up for success. If you end up under a manager that do not know what they're doing (to determine this ask them technical questions and see whether they have at least some level of informed answer) aim to move to another team sooner than later.
* Tied to the previous point, your direct manager can see when you apply for other positions in the company, know that this has the potential to sour the relationship with your manager which can impact your career opportunities at the company.
* Engineers that stay at the company for a long time has to essentially work themselves into positions that are isolated from all the bureaucracy, red tape and potential cross team dependencies (think positions like code modernization that does not have a lot of cross team dependencies besides getting PR approvals).

The “values” are performative and they use growth mindset as a crutch to continue to cause disruption rather than making strategic decisions. Overall it’s a very “meetings about nothing” culture, everything gets offloaded to vendors and partners so you’re mainly babysitting rather than participating in meaningful work. Microsoft may be printing money, but the amount of waste is unbelievable. And when I talk about waste, it’s not the people, it’s the vendor relationships and frequent pivots. This all culminates in zero work like balance, especially if you do not live near campus.

Pros:
1. Strong hourly rate:
$60/hour translates to approximately $124,800 annually if working full-time (40 hours/week, 52 weeks), which is solid—especially for contract work.

2. Brand prestige:
Having Microsoft on your résumé can open doors to future opportunities, even at higher rates.

3. Creative influence at scale:
You’ll likely work on high-visibility projects, contributing to products or campaigns seen by millions.

4. Flexible work structure:
Contract roles often come with remote or hybrid options and fewer meetings or internal politics.

5. Potential for renewal or internal referrals:
Success in the role could lead to longer-term contracts or even full-time opportunities within Microsoft.
Cons:
1. No benefits:
As a contractor, you probably won’t receive health insurance, paid vacation, or stock options—those are reserved for full-time employees.

2. Inconsistent hours:
Contract work may not guarantee 40 hours/week consistently, which affects total take-home pay.

3. No paid holidays or sick days:
Unless negotiated, days off are usually unpaid.

4. Limited internal influence:
Contractors may have less say in strategic direction or access to internal resources and systems.

5. Taxes & admin overhead:
You’re likely considered self-employed, so you’ll need to set aside taxes, manage invoicing, and potentially deal with HST if you're in Canada.

Pros:
--Very good compensation and benefits
--Opportunity to work in a domain I'm passionate about
--Coworkers and managers almost without exception were smart, helpful and very decent folks
--I was on the low end of the scale for stock options, but it was still enough to be a substantial boost to my nest egg
--Being with one of the top tech companies provides a strong credibility factor
--Diversity is an important part of the culture
Cons:
--Little to no opportunity to expand into other areas beyond what they hired you for. They probably have other people who are already doing that and you can't "step on toes".
--Much talk of personal growth and training, but ultimately that was left up to me to pursue on my own.
--Could never get a firm answer to the question "what should I be doing to advance my career?" Promotions *do* happen, but it seemed like it was determined more by a pre-planned schedule than anything I had control over.
--I had many ideas for ways to help the team but they were almost always ignored. Seemed like if it wasn't thought up by a senior manager, it wasn't worth considering.
--My "official" manager was someone I would sometimes not talk to for months at a time. The actual day to day management was delegated to someone else.

Pros: Generous attention to health and well-being (could be lip service, of course); great food on campus; surface-level promotion of diversity and inclusion (my experience could have been an outlier, being one of two people on my team who didn't belong to the same ethnic group, with the only other employee of a different background having left the team between the time I trained them and my return from parental leave)
Cons:
Preface - Received my first LITE (MS PIP) after over three years with the company, two weeks before the May 2025 layoffs

-The low performance claim was based mainly on brand new tasks, involving only three weeks of training for tasks on platforms with which I had no familiarity. Furthermore, despite receiving instruction to not include future ongoing/new tasks for this Connects (performance review) season, and training having only begun three weeks before the Connects call took place, these tasks occupied a significant portion of my performance evaluation for this Connects. One of these tasks centered around a tool that I verified via screenshare with the co-worker training me that it was providing incorrect numbers despite correct inputs, something I immediately remedied upon some lengthy troubleshooting but could not have known prior. I was also cited for not updating tags on a handful of content, when I had originally only been instructed to update the tag for one article. I then immediately remedied this once learning the additional tags were necessary, but not before the co-worker who trained me copied our manager on an email laying out these issues rather than addressing me about them first.

-Retroactive reasons given for low performance, counter to evidence: Another reason given for the LITE was allegedly not creating a user feedback synthesis with which I was tasked to create alone – even though I had created it alone, only for management to instruct another co-worker to create a second synthesis to which the whole team would contribute. When I asked, I was given no reason why they were not using my version, nor informed that this had been formally updated into a team effort (which evidently come this Connects season, it had been reverted to only my task again). Notwithstanding, I still contributed most of the content to the synthesis and organized a prototype design to propose a product feature based on the synthesized customer feedback.

-Retroactive reasons for low performance #2: It was claimed that I was taken off of a reports-based role due to “repeated glaring issues”, yet at the time, this was not given as the reason. At the time, I was juggling most of the reports for the team due to time zone, and those who took over from me have experienced similar occasional complaints from our partner team, suggesting issues that had arisen under my watch over an extended period just appeared to be repeated/numerous, as I was carrying most of that effort. Most of these issues involved technical trouble with our content management system which were debilitating enough that we had to migrate platforms, with the others mainly being our partners not wanting our team to conduct such meticulous reviews (despite this having been the review style on which I and others who joined around the same time were trained and having been docked once for allegedly not reviewing one report closely enough upon return from parental leave, I committed even more strongly to thoroughness). Instead, I was told at the time that I was taken off reports, because they needed someone full-time for another initiative. For the past year, I have received wonderful feedback on metrics goals I have achieved with this program. However, after being the only one on the team to not receive a raise or promotion despite only positive Connects/bonuses over three years at the company and seven years of previous industry experience, during our previous Connects season in December 2024, I asked what I could do to improve and was told that I needed more visibility and given a rundown of the role/band's subjective expectation categories - all of which I was able to speak to. To improve impact, I joined another initiative to enhance my existing initiative. The positive feedback received from three different Perspectives (peer reviews) regarding innovation for driving customer success and revenue were ignored and for the most part, this customer success and visibility initiative was discouraged by direct management. 

-Perspectives potentially influenced by management: A co-worker who is a senior on my team but who has never managed or trained me before the past three weeks working on one of these new tasks framed their feedback as if they were my manager, summing up my entire career at Microsoft and claiming I should be much further than I was, despite never having worked with me directly or overseen my tasks prior to the past month. They referenced a tool we have never used in our work together (but that another co-worker in their time zone has which suggests collaboration in writing this critique but was already covered by the other co-worker in their Perspective) and deliverable types we never worked on together. Furthermore, I was called out for “recurring” issues which were actually all unique from each other and stemming from lack of prior awareness (such as being told that required information was in the training video when it wasn’t, and that I made an inconvenient oversight in an email when it turned out the email in question was actually in an entirely different thread sent earlier on). By and large, while mitigating these hiccups are my responsibility and I am always ready to do so, some could not have been avoided until other factors came to light, so they seem to have been used as a paper trail to reflect negligence.

I had suspected that collaboration might have been occurring behind the scenes when the Connect Tool during last Connects season informed me that management had requested me to ask for a Perspective from a teammate with whom I hadn’t worked in two years but who was a principal member of the team, despite my having already requested Perspectives from five different folks. I was ultimately thankful for this peer’s feedback, as it was overall quite constructive and said that I took feedback very well, which countered what my manager’s comments have claimed - even if the feedback was regarding a task on which I no longer worked (hence us not having collaborated for two years). This could have been at the time due to the situation not being as dire as initially expected last Connects season, despite the performance-based layoffs already kicking off at the time. Once again, it would have been more lucrative to just explain that the report reviewing style (the only capacity in which we worked together) had changed rather than sequester me to a narrow role that has evidently minimal visibility.

While I understand that Microsoft is in a tough spot with these performance-driven and RIF layoffs, I wanted to craft this response, following a Connects call that was very rushed and had such poor audio quality from the manager’s side that I had to rely more on reading the comments than conversing and was not able to pose any questions before they had to end the call. I wanted to summarily assure that, despite my layoff, our team goals and my career at Microsoft have meant so much to me, and that, despite taking parental leave, I have remained ever-committed.

Pros: The flexibility (remote, hybrid, in office) was great until they became obsessed with cutting cost. Discretionary time off was one of the worst things to happen to this company.
Cons:
Your growth in a job often depends on your team and your relationship with your manager.

Unfortunately, I had a hard time with a manager who wasn’t respectful. They used Discretionary Time Off (DTO) unfairly against me. For example, after I worked an on-call shift, my boss told me I couldn’t take the compensatory day off like others because I had recently taken my birthday off.

It was also hard to get time off approved. Last year, I only managed to take about 10 days off—my birthday and a five-day trip I had planned. I wasn’t even able to take time off for Christmas.

There were times when my manager made me feel embarrassed in front of my team, even though they would later say they “had my back.” When I tried to share feedback, it was brushed aside, and they would talk about their own personal struggles instead. Despite getting poor ratings as a manager, they didn’t seem to make changes to improve.

That said, this experience was only with one manager. My other managers before this were supportive and professional.

Pros: Great business model means we actually get money from the people we make the product for, so our incentive is to make the product good (and safe and private etc) for them rather than stick ads everywhere.
Cons: The culture has gone radically downhill in the last 2+ years since the advent of generative AI. It's as if all of senior leadership suddenly forgot why they led a positive cultural transformation 10 years ago. But that cultural transformation was made us great as a company, more productive and profitable. So...we might be in trouble.

Cons:
Microsoft is a huge company, and it's really difficult to make a generalization about the entire company.

However, recently, they've changed how vacations work by leaving it to manager's discretion which has absolutely destroyed the work life balance. Managers will ask for you to plan your vacations 6 months to a year in advance. They'll guilt trip you into not taking a vacation or taking a shorter vacation. They'll tell you how hard they work to discourage you from taking time off.

There are so many stories that both I and other people in my team and org have about these types of manipulation tactics from managers. Managers have to act like this because our leadership is secretly cutting costs and focusing on "productivity" at the expense of work-life balance, manager respect, and family.

Pros:
(chatgpt-anonomized, my thoughts)
The management team is exceptional—highly technical and deeply understanding of the engineering experience within the organization.
The projects here operate at an extraordinary scale—arguably among the largest in the world, easily within the top three by size.
The work involves tackling unprecedented challenges in networking across a diverse range of sub-domains.
There's the opportunity to contribute, albeit somewhat indirectly, to groundbreaking technology initiatives.
Work-life balance is strong; while the team is hardworking and highly skilled, the workload is managed within humane hours.
Competence across the team is notably high. While the organization may not always have a top-tier reputation overall, the level of expertise within the Azure Networking group stands out as exceptionally strong, surpassing much of the broader organization.

For those who are queer or part of other marginalized groups, the environment is inclusive and respectful. It’s a remarkable place to focus on meaningful work without fear of harassment, bullying, or being overlooked—unfortunately, still a rare quality in many workplaces.
Cons:
Compensation tends to be lower compared to other major tech companies.
Promotion timelines appear to follow a fairly rigid structure, though this may evolve over time.

At one time, this was a great, reliable company to work for. I had a medical condition that required some time off and it resulted in a poor review over the Sept 2024 cycle. When I took care of the condition, I received constant feedback that things were going well and I had turned things around... but then I got fired without severance or anything in early 2025, citing the specific review that was poor. 22 years and simply shown the door.

Microsoft was a company I believed in, defended and worked hard for. To be dismissed so casually was heart-breaking.

In today's environment, there is NO room for mistakes, because in this case, my mistake cost me everything.

Pros:
Challenging and Impactful Work: The role of a Senior Program Manager at Microsoft is both challenging and rewarding. You get to work on cutting-edge technologies and manage projects that have a real impact on millions of users worldwide. The scope and scale of the work are incredible, and you constantly feel like you’re contributing to something meaningful.

Collaborative Culture: Microsoft’s culture is one of collaboration and teamwork. You’re surrounded by some of the brightest minds in the industry, and there’s a strong emphasis on sharing knowledge and helping each other succeed. The company fosters a supportive environment where everyone’s ideas are valued and innovation is encouraged.

Opportunities for Growth: Microsoft is deeply committed to the growth and development of its employees. As a Senior Program Manager, I’ve had numerous opportunities to attend training sessions, gain new certifications, and take on new responsibilities. The company offers clear pathways for career advancement, and leadership is genuinely invested in your success.

Work-Life Balance: Microsoft understands the importance of work-life balance and offers flexible work arrangements to accommodate different needs. The company’s commitment to employee well-being is evident in its comprehensive benefits package, generous vacation policies, and support for mental health and wellness.

Diversity and Inclusion: Microsoft places a high priority on diversity and inclusion, creating a workplace where everyone feels welcome and valued. The company actively promotes diversity in its hiring practices and provides numerous resources and support networks to ensure that all employees have the opportunity to succeed.
Cons: High Expectations: The role is demanding, and there is a high expectation to deliver results. However, the support and resources provided make it possible to meet these expectations and excel in the role.

Pros: Lots of fun fringe benefits, get to see the glint of jealousy in everyone's eyes when you tell them you work at Microsoft, and no you weren't a CS major. Got to work with some of the most supportive and interesting folks I've had the privilege of working with.
Cons: Scope of the job drastically inflated over the 3 years I was there, mostly tasks focused around supporting the sales teams that weren't making their numbers and trying desperately to prop up the AI revolution.

Pros:
Had an awesome team, deeply dedicated to their domain of expertise. Loved the work I did with them. 

The pay and benefits were really good comparatively to other companies.

Did I say how awesome the ICs and my team was.... great, kind, humble (most of them anyway)
Cons:
My new boss was toxic: I was screamed at, humiliated, and gaslit for; 6 months. I dropped 30 pounds from the stress and was throwing up every morning when my boss called threatening my career and livelihood. I was a high performer under my prior boss, the only difference now - the CVP above me that I reported to. They were a terror.

CVP purposefully set out to destroy our team. Cut our team resources to nothing and then demanded we hit the same KPIs/ "Do more with less". CVP withheld critical information to make the team look less effective than other parts of their business. Very nasty/intentional -- played a game of favoritism and game of thrones. Very political. 

HR is often weaponized by underperformers - those people then abuse managers through blind survey or filing illegitimate complaints.. No one ever held accountable for filing BS claims - can say nasty things about you and degrade you; while their lawyers try to extort the company for money. Ugly game. HR does nothing to protect front line manager. HR irrelevant and not helpful, only objectives - protect the company and $ -- use a corrupt process. 

Became concerned for my safety and my family's safety as one employee that was mentally unhealthy threatened me personally. 

The most toxic environment imaginable.

Pros: Microsoft fosters a collaborative and inclusive work culture. The company places a strong emphasis on work-life balance, and leadership generally respects employees' time and personal commitments. While expectations are high, the environment is not overly stressful, and there's a strong focus on productivity rather than just hours worked.
Cons: While Microsoft offers many benefits, there are some drawbacks to consider. Being a large corporation, bureaucracy can sometimes slow down decision-making and innovation, especially compared to smaller, more agile companies. Team experiences can vary significantly, and some teams may have higher workloads or on-call rotations that impact work-life balance. Promotions can be competitive, requiring strong visibility and alignment with leadership goals. Additionally, while the company embraces hybrid work, some teams and projects may have more rigid expectations around in-office presence. Lastly, like any big tech company, navigating internal politics can be necessary for career advancement.

- Some toxic, high-intensity, brash team members (but generally many were friendly and kind people)

Pros:
As an Application Innovation Specialist Azure at Microsoft, I have had the privilege of working from home, which has greatly enhanced my work-life balance. The flexibility to visit customers and meet them at our offices without the daily commute is a significant benefit.

Microsoft is led by a visionary leadership team, and the company's strong performance in the stock market is a testament to their effective strategy and direction. I feel proud to be part of an organization that not only excels in its industry but also fosters a positive and inclusive work environment.

The people at Microsoft are truly the best of the best. The collaborative and innovative culture here is inspiring and motivates me to perform at my highest level. Additionally, the compensation and health care benefits are phenomenal.

Overall, I highly recommend Microsoft as a great place to work, where you can grow professionally and be part of a forward-thinking team.
Cons: For some people the switching of managers often. If this is an issue, this is probably not the place for you.

Pros:
1.	Opportunity to Work with Innovation
Microsoft is a leader in technology, offering access to cutting-edge projects, tools, and technologies. Product managers contribute to creating products that impact millions of people worldwide.
	2.	Competitive Compensation and Benefits
Microsoft provides competitive salaries, attractive bonuses, stock options, and other financial incentives.
	3.	Global Recognition
Working at Microsoft adds prestige and value to your resume, opening doors to new opportunities in the tech industry.
	4.	Learning and Development
	•	Access to internal courses, training programs, and certifications.
	•	Participation in conferences, workshops, and other professional development events.
	5.	Flexibility and Work-Life Balance
	•	Many teams operate in hybrid or fully remote formats.
	•	Additional leave options and employee support programs help maintain a healthy work-life balance.
Cons:
1.	High Pressure and Expectations
	•	Microsoft operates in a fast-paced, high-stakes environment where product managers are expected to deliver significant results.
	•	Meeting deadlines and maintaining the quality of global-impact products can be stressful.
	2.	Complex Organizational Structure
	•	Being a large corporation, Microsoft has a complex hierarchy and decision-making process, which can slow down initiatives or lead to bureaucracy.
	•	Gaining alignment across multiple teams and stakeholders may require extra effort.
	3.	Long Working Hours
	•	Product managers may need to work extended hours, especially when dealing with cross-functional teams in different time zones or during product launches.
	•	Work-life balance can be challenging in certain roles.

Pros: It’s structured and lean to complete.
Cons:
Every year there are commitments that do not always align with the specifics of the geography or area hence not achievable no matter how hard you work. The core commitments are defined at the headquarters and cascaded down to each management layer across the organization where additional objectives are added to the core commitment to meet each managements own objectives, In the end review commitments are a bunch of metrics that either impacts negatively the customer or the technology/service. Example, product/service software developers are evaluated by the number broken code issues before releasing a product/service. A common practice is to avoid raising awareness or fix any malfunctioning code until the product/service is released. This practice reduces the chances of a malfunctioning code harming developers evaluation and hence their bonus, that’s why after a release of products, service or technology the fixes patches etc. are always high. Seems like any product, service or technology isn’t ready to be released but the bonus is fulfilled due to the way the developers are evaluated. It’s vicious. If you raise concerns about this, you may end up fired. Remember, Microsoft's business culture and values are more important than employees' personal cultures and values. 
Finally, at Microsoft nowadays, if you are not originally or descended from India, your chances to grow your career there are lower in comparison to Indians.

Pros:
*Lots of opportunity to learn. Frequent tech sessions covering all kinds of topics.
*Microsoft has always been known for having great benefits. This is still true today. 
*Mostly remote work
Cons:
*Lack of agility. When something isn't working, it's difficult to convince leadership to pivot.
* Confusing titles. Titles often don't reflect the actual role. This leads to confusion when dealing with customers and partners.
* Position was FTE with MS, but hourly rather salary. This meant PTO was accrued rather than unlimited like regular salaried employees. No adequate explanation for this was ever given other than it was required for employees whose comp included a certain percentage of commission.
*Lack of understanding of how to use their own tools. Teams was just a chat tool and Dynamics was messy.

Pros: Microsoft offers a fantastic work environment with a strong culture of innovation and collaboration. The company emphasizes employee well-being, providing great benefits, flexible work options, and learning opportunities. Leadership is generally supportive, and there’s room for growth across teams and roles. Work-life balance is respected in most divisions, and the scale of projects allows for meaningful impact. The inclusive and diverse culture adds to the positive experience.
Cons: Honestly, I didn’t experience any significant downsides during my time at Microsoft. The work culture, opportunities, and overall environment exceeded my expectations.

Pros:
Love working at Microsoft for the most part, the pay is mediocre compared to other big tech companies, but it is in not inherently bad. The benefits make it worth it in my opinion, healthcare doesn't come out of each paycheck, for example.

Great company culture, love the "growth mindset" focus. Have had 3 managers in 3 years. My teams and managers have always been respectful and encouraging.
Cons:
On call can be stressful - team dependent.
Some internal systems and tools that have existed for decades. Learning them can be weird and doesn't always translate to other companies well.

Promotion velocity has been slow despite being consistently praised in performance reviews, managers agreeing I am already performing at next level, etc.

Pros:
Diverse Projects – You get to work on a wide variety of industries and solutions, keeping the work engaging and dynamic.
Access to Cutting-Edge Technology – Opportunities to stay at the forefront of technology with access to Microsoft’s latest tools and platforms.
Collaborative Environment – A supportive team culture that encourages collaboration and sharing of best practices.
Career Development – Plenty of internal training programs and certifications to help you grow and specialize further.
Work-Life Balance – Flexible work hours and remote opportunities make balancing professional and personal commitments manageable.
Cons:
High Expectations – The fast-paced environment demands high levels of performance and accountability, which can feel stressful at times.
Complex Solutions – Some projects involve highly intricate technical solutions that require significant upskilling.
Client Challenges – Managing demanding clients with tight deadlines can be overwhelming.
Internal Processes – Navigating through Microsoft’s large organizational structure and bureaucracy can be slow and frustrating.
Workload Peaks – There are occasional periods of intense workload, especially close to project deadlines or fiscal year-end.

Pros:
For mechanical and electrical engineers, pay is 2x to 3X what any non tech company pays. And an engineer is less accountable because the hardware teams expect to fail. 
Benefits are premium. Best 401k match on the planet. Health benefit of $3,000 to spend on bikes, hiking and fitness gear etc. Beer kegs exist in most project rooms. And there’s no need to advance your skills beyond what you learned in college. They run their hardware orgs like college design projects not like commercial product development companies.
Cons:
Because top pay and frequent failure go hand in hand, the orgs are political. Many directors, general managers and some of the VPs are more motivated to protect their status and compensation instead of trying to improve the organization. And so the hardware groups fail and lose money. 

The worst is the politics that arise due to leaders protecting themselves. And folks deep down know they are less deserving of accolades and higher pay and bonuses than their peers in other industries. So while they post how amazing hogging out space for a motherboard on an aluminum brick is, they avoid mirrors that will reveal the truth. They are locusts.

And finally, internally it was admitted that the company wants to get rid of all white men over 45. As a hiring manager
I took a class in which the instructor stated that. And recruiters also told me that they were not allowed to present resumes to me of anyone over 50.

Pros:
Innovative Environment: Microsoft consistently pushes the boundaries of technology, offering employees the opportunity to work on groundbreaking projects that shape the future of the tech industry.
Excellent Work-Life Balance: The company values work-life balance, offering flexible working hours and remote work options, which is great for maintaining a healthy work-life integration.
Supportive Culture: The collaborative and inclusive culture at Microsoft fosters a supportive environment where employees can thrive and grow both personally and professionally.
Career Development: Microsoft provides extensive resources for career development, including training programs, mentorship opportunities, and a clear path for advancement within the company.
Comprehensive Benefits: The benefits package is competitive, including healthcare, retirement plans, and generous vacation time, ensuring employees are well taken care of.
Cons:
Large Corporate Structure: As a large company, navigating through the layers of management and bureaucracy can be challenging, sometimes slowing down decision-making processes.
High Expectations: The performance expectations are high, which can lead to a demanding work environment and pressure to consistently deliver top results.
Frequent Reorganization: Microsoft undergoes frequent reorganizations, which can create uncertainty and disrupt team dynamics, making it difficult to adapt to new roles and responsibilities.
Intense Competition: The competitive nature within the company, particularly in certain divisions, can sometimes feel overwhelming and may affect work-life balance during peak periods.
Complex Internal Systems: The internal tools and systems used at Microsoft can be complex and require time to learn, which may slow down onboarding for new employees.

Pros: Engaging and motivating work. My family and friends loved telling people I worked there. The pay and benefits are amazing as well. Theoretically there's a lot of room to grow and change teams. It looks good on my resume now.
Cons:
Zero job security or advancement:

Reviews only happen twice a year. I worked there for 2.5 years with "no budget for raises or promotions". One or two people in the entire org got promoted once a year. After my first year, there was an internal hiring freeze that kept anyone from even changing teams.

Shortly after my fourth glowing performance review, I was part of the 10k people laid off in spring 2023. Though the announcement was made in January, the layoffs were rolling for months. I was a part of the very last ones, laid off in a group of 12 people by my 5th level skip, to make room for more people to work on their terrible AI. 

Disorganized chaos:

Agile/scrum is industry standard but it still hasn't caught on at Microsoft. If you need structure, clear requirements, etc., make sure that's something the team you're going to join cares about. My org only started doing *quarterly* planning for engineering in late 2022.

I'm back as a contractor now in a different org and it's actually even worse. They don't even do quarterly planning.

Every organization and team have different cultures around planning, expectations, documentation, etc. If you're thinking about joining make sure to talk to your individual manager about it.

Pros: Microsoft fosters an innovative and dynamic work culture, providing employees with significant opportunities for career growth and development. The company offers excellent benefits and resources, creating a strong foundation for employee success. The collaborative environment and focus on technology advancement make it a rewarding place to work.
Cons: While the company excels in innovation, some management practices can negatively impact the employee experience. There are instances where the prioritization of company needs over employee well-being is evident, which can affect morale. Additionally, the transparency of feedback processes, particularly regarding surveys that claim to be anonymous, raises concerns, as providing honest feedback may sometimes lead to unintended consequences.

Pros: As a Program Manager, I’ve found that Microsoft offers a lot of variety in the projects I manage, which keeps my work engaging and challenging. I appreciate the autonomy I have in decision-making, as it allows me to drive projects forward without constant oversight. The team culture is very supportive, and I’ve had many positive experiences working across departments to solve complex issues. There are great opportunities for career development, and the leadership training has really helped me grow in my role. Work-life balance is also respected, with flexible work hours that help me manage my personal time effectively.
Cons: One downside I’ve experienced is the heavy workload, especially when managing high-priority projects. The pace can become overwhelming, particularly when resources are stretched thin. Communication between departments could be improved, as there are times when it feels like information is siloed, slowing down project progress. Some processes can feel unnecessarily bureaucratic, making it difficult to push through decisions quickly. Lastly, the performance expectations can create pressure, especially during project launches, which can make the role feel a bit stressful at times.

Pros: Working at this company has its share of positives. The work itself is engaging and meaningful, providing a good balance of challenges and learning opportunities. The facilities are top-notch, offering a comfortable and well-equipped environment that makes the daily grind much easier. Perhaps one of the biggest advantages is the freedom to make decisions. Employees are given a lot of autonomy in their roles, which fosters creativity and innovation. This level of trust is rare and makes you feel genuinely valued as part of the team.
Cons: However, the company is not without its downsides. The on-call rotations can be extremely frustrating, often feeling like a burden rather than a necessary duty. What's more concerning is that management seems indifferent to this issue, leaving employees to handle the stress on their own. Another major drawback is that many talented individuals are stuck supporting legacy products that seem to be on the brink of collapse. This not only wastes potential but also creates uncertainty about the future. Personal growth is another area where the company falls short. Despite the hard work and contributions, salary hikes are questionable, making it difficult to feel motivated in the long run.

The mental abuse and cultlike tendencies are also insane they will make you feel crazy by gaslighting you with numbers, I was even told where else will you go this is Microsoft when speaking with a manager. Mentally prepare for corporate politics and mental daily gymnastics. The clients are amazing, but management made everything bad by ignoring when we did well to stuff Microsoft's pockets and forgoing our raises even though we had the highest performing quarter in company history during covid. Pros: Access to so many great resources whether it's tools or partnerships with other tier 1 brands. Scale of projects is amazing with a real opportunity to impact so many people and processes. Fantastic benefits and a flexible work environment.
Cons: Constant change including budget freezes and significant departmental re-organizations mean many projects rarely make it to completion. It becomes a game of whack-a-mole where you quickly learn that the single most important thing is managing your internal brand and evangelizing for yourself at every possible opportunity. There is no such thing as "what's best for the company/team". If you are a heads-down, non-self-promoting type of hard worker, you'll quickly burn out. This is a culture that only recognizes extreme extroverts with big mouths and not much substance. Managing-up is virtually all that matters.

Pros: The health insurance benefits were by far the biggest plus.
Cons: In terms of tech, MSFT's pay was often lower than other companies due to "its great culture". Things like work life balance, job security, and insurance were big selling a points. However, culture is not real world currency and culture quickly shifts depending on your org or the company priorities. The main selling points for receiving lower pay seemed to fade away over the years. Great mangers are crucial but certain orgs have more bad mangers and leadership than good ones. It makes the chances of getting a good manger, a good team, and good leadership very rare. but it's great for those who can get the trifecta.

Pros:
I had the privilege of working at Microsoft, and I can confidently say it’s one of the best companies in the world. The company prioritizes its employees' well-being and growth, offering a wide range of resources and services both during your time at Microsoft and even after you've moved on.

The culture at Microsoft fosters innovation, inclusivity, and collaboration. The benefits are top-notch, from health and wellness programs to professional development initiatives that empower employees to reach their full potential.

What stands out most to me is Microsoft’s commitment to supporting its employees even after they leave. Their alumni network is strong, and they offer valuable resources to ensure that you continue to thrive in your career.

If you’re looking for a company that will invest in your future and values work-life balance, Microsoft is unparalleled. I’m incredibly grateful for my experience and highly recommend it to anyone seeking a fulfilling career.
Cons: No significant cons from my experience.

Pros: Microsoft has so many internal resources with great opportunities for learning. I've worked on various teams and there is a lot of interesting work and contributions are valued. One of the many things the company values is a growth mindset and we regularly look at and discuss our process and take steps to improve them. Each team has the flexibility to do this in the manner that works best for them. We also have lots of great opportunities for cross team collaboration and it's fun to work with other teams and learn about how they do things.
Cons: The work is interesting, but with constantly scheduled deliverables and deadlines it can be challenging to take advantage of the great resources the company provides. It's important for you to make the time for personal growth.

Pros: I worked with lots of good people, competent, smart and helpful. The benefits are decent, especially the 50% match on 401K contributions. Microsoft is a company of many "companies". While overall compensation and review process is the same, each team is unique in its code base, operations, available projects to work on and most importantly, how well it is managed. Your direct manager is crucial for you success in your career but so are also upper levels of management that set the tone in the organization.
Cons: Promotion process is opaque and lacks clarity on how decisions are achieved. Heavy process and red-tape can frustrate daily software development work, especially in large organization inside Microsoft (even if they use "Agile").

Pros:
Innovative Projects: Constant exposure to cutting-edge technology and impactful projects.
Great Work-Life Balance: Flexible hours and remote work options.
Strong Compensation & Benefits: Competitive salary, stock options, and top-tier health benefits.
Collaborative Culture: Supportive teams and opportunities to collaborate with top talent.
Career Growth Opportunities: Clear pathways for advancement and continuous learning through training and mentorship.
Cons: Bureaucracy: The company’s size can sometimes slow decision-making and innovation.

Pros: I loved all the benefits provided by Microsoft. It was honestly hard to keep track of everything to ensure that I got the value out of it all, but that's a good problem to have
Cons:
You know how Microsoft is supposed to be the chill big tech company with a great work life balance? That might be true in some sections of the company, but my team and the org around us was not that. At one point we hired someone from AWS to the team, and after a few months she left to return to her old job because the work life balance was so much better. Our WLB score on the employee survey was 20/100, whereas the average across all of Microsoft was 75/100. Microsoft pay isn't enough to put up with the BS we had to deal with.

I used to think that they cared a good deal about diversity and inclusion, until they laid off their entire DEI team

Pros:
Health Benefits and Financial Planning: Extensive health benefits and financial planning options.

40-Hour Work Week: Generally offers a good work-life balance.

Updated Tools and Resources: Access to cutting-edge technology and resources.

Stability: Known for job security and consistent work.

Resume Booster: Prestigious company name that looks great on your resume.
Cons:
Competition for Advancement: Can be challenging to get promoted due to the large number of employees.

Isolation: Some employees feel isolated due to the company's size.

Promoting Within: Preference for internal hires can limit opportunities for external candidates.

Not Much Variation: Some roles may lack variety and creativity.

Performance Reviews: The stack ranking system can create a competitive and stressful environment.

Pros: Nice people to work with; people treat you with respect

Pros:
From the web

Competitive Compensation: Microsoft offers an average salary of $120,000, insurance coverage for employees and their families, fitness center reimbursement, education reimbursement, paid leave, and a flexible work schedule3.
Innovation and Impact: Microsoft is constantly innovating and expanding its reach into new areas. It is a place where you can make an impact and see the results of your work. The company offers a great work/life balance, competitive salaries, and excellent benefits4.
Career Growth: Microsoft provides opportunities for career growth, work-life balance, and a positive work culture. Employees have the chance to collaborate with talented people and work on exciting projects5.
Cons:
From the web

Competition for Advancement: The competition for promotions and career advancement can be intense, which might not be suitable for everyone1.
Isolation: Some employees may feel isolated due to the large size of the company1.
Lack of Variation: The job roles may not have much variation, leading to monotony for some employees1.
Performance Reviews: The performance review process can be stressful and may not always be perceived as fair1.

Cons:
Workload Can Be Intense: High expectations can sometimes lead to longer working hours, especially during project deadlines.

On-Call Rotations: Rotational on-call duties, while manageable, can be stressful when balancing other projects.

Pros:
Excellent internal learning resources and active social communities, support for fully remote work in most cases. You get exposure to vast knowledge bases to help understand advanced technologies and access to people who can explain it so their grandparents would understand. 
I've had very positive relationships with my managers, and even in times of upheaval, our leadership tends to index towards clarity with the general staff.
Cons:
Every job posting receives 100+ resumes from both internal and external candidates, so external applicants have a high barrier of entry unless they know someone who can make an intro or have such a perfected resume that it gets past HR filters and to the desk of a hiring manager that has at most 10-30 seconds to look at it.

Specific to cybersecurity, Microsoft tends to hire more experienced people and needs to do a better job growing early in career cybersecurity professionals.

Pros: Great benefits including a lump sum available annually for mental and physical wellbeing to include things like spa services, hair services, manicures, pet sitting, childcare, etc.

Once they acquired the DAX software and they incorporated their AI/copilot software, it was only a matter of time before our roles were eliminated. The layoff was abrupt and unexpected, as they often are, but they have provided "resources" to help us in our career transition. As a whole, Microsoft couldn't have cared less about us.

Pros:
Cutting-Edge Technology: As a pioneer in the tech industry, Microsoft offers exposure to the latest cybersecurity tools, technologies, and research. This environment fosters continuous learning and growth.
Impactful Role: Given Microsoft's vast user base, cybersecurity professionals play a critical role in protecting billions of users globally. The work has a significant impact on digital security.
Career Growth: Microsoft is known for its strong emphasis on employee development. Cybersecurity professionals have ample opportunities for career advancement, with potential paths into leadership or specialized roles.
Cons:
High Pressure: Given the scale of Microsoft's operations and the constant evolution of cyber threats, cybersecurity professionals often face high-pressure situations and demanding workloads.
Burnout Risk: The fast-paced nature of the cybersecurity industry, coupled with the criticality of the role, can lead to burnout if not managed effectively.

Pros: As far as big corporations go, Microsoft is one of the best ones to work. The company culture is overall great. They emphasize a growth mindset and try to care about people. They have strong emphasis on diversity and inclusion which helps everyone think about how to create a more welcoming and inclusive environment. The pay and benefits are competitive. Because of all the products they work on, you can work on different products and move teams without leaving the company. They’re also making a lot of great strategic decisions which gives me faith in the leadership and direction they’re headed.
Cons:
While the company culture overall is good and they try to emphasize good values, it’s a huge company so you can have a vast difference in experience depending on where you work. If you’re interviewing, make sure you meet with your hiring manager, evaluate them and ask questions about the culture of the team. 
A lot of work is still Seattle centric which makes it difficult to be visible if you’re new and remote, impacting promotions, influence, etc.
If you’re getting hired for a PM position, make sure you understand what is expected from the role. It looks vastly different depending on the product and its needs. I would recommend staying away from products that aren’t growing, especially as a PM.
